guards.name: Closed Guard üîí
guards.description: The closed guard is one of the fundamental positions in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. It involves wrapping your legs around your opponent's waist while lying on your back, creating a tight control that prevents them from passing.
execution: Lie on your back with your opponent between your legs
Lock your ankles behind their back at the lower back
Use your legs to break their posture by pulling them down
Control their sleeves or collar with your hands for grip control
Keep your hips active and mobile - never flat
Squeeze your knees together to prevent space
Keep your shoulders slightly off the mat to stay active
Use angle changes by moving your hips side to side
Maintain constant pressure with your legs to control distance
pros: Excellent control over opponent's posture and movement
Multiple submission opportunities from secure position
Prevents opponent from advancing position effectively
Great for beginners to learn fundamental guard concepts
Allows you to rest while opponent works
Safe position to attack from with low risk
Works well in self-defense scenarios
cons: Can be difficult against standing opponents
Uses significant energy to maintain against strong opponents
Less effective in No-Gi due to lack of grips
Limited mobility compared to open guards
Can be stalled by defensive opponents
Vulnerable to guard breaks from experienced passers
Restricted attacking angles compared to open guard
tips: Always break your opponent's posture first - this is priority #1
Use angle changes to create submission opportunities
Don't let your opponent establish a strong base or posture
Practice hip escapes to maintain and adjust the guard
Open your guard strategically to transition, not passively
Combine attacks - if one fails, chain to another immediately
Use overhooks and underhooks to control their arms
Keep your guard high on their back for better control
Don't cross your ankles when in mount - only in guard
Practice breaking grips to prevent guard opening

sweeps.name: Scissor Sweep
sweeps.description: Classic sweep using a scissoring motion with your legs to off-balance and sweep your opponent.

sweeps.name: Flower Sweep (Pendulum)
sweeps.description: Use your legs to elevate and sweep when opponent posts their hand.

sweeps.name: Hip Bump Sweep
sweeps.description: Sit up and use your hip to bump opponent backwards while controlling their arm.

sweeps.name: Overhead Sweep
sweeps.description: Pull opponent forward and sweep them over your head with momentum.

sweeps.name: Elevator Sweep
sweeps.description: Use your leg like an elevator to lift and sweep opponent to the side.

sweeps.name: Sit-up Sweep
sweeps.description: Sit up into opponent, control their back, and sweep them forward.

sweeps.name: Kimura Sweep
sweeps.description: Use kimura grip to break posture and sweep when they defend.

sweeps.name: Arm Drag to Back Take
sweeps.description: Drag their arm across and take the back for technical sweep or back control.

sweeps.name: Butterfly Sweep (from closed)
sweeps.description: Open guard to butterfly hooks and sweep immediately.

sweeps.name: Double Ankle Sweep
sweeps.description: Control both ankles when they stand and sweep their base.

sweeps.name: Shoulder Walk Sweep
sweeps.description: Walk your shoulders under opponent and elevate to sweep.

sweeps.name: Loop Choke Sweep
sweeps.description: Use loop choke setup to off-balance and sweep when they defend.

passes.name: Standing Pass
passes.description: Break the closed guard by standing up and controlling the knees to pass.

passes.name: Double Under Pass
passes.description: Pass by getting both arms under the legs after opening the guard.

passes.name: Knee Slice Pass
passes.description: Open guard and slice knee across to side control.

passes.name: Toreando Pass
passes.description: Stand, control pants, and throw legs to side to pass around.

passes.name: Leg Drag Pass
passes.description: Open guard and drag their leg across their body to pass.

passes.name: Stack Pass
passes.description: Drive their knees to chest, stack their weight, and pass around.

passes.name: Pressure Pass (over-under)
passes.description: One arm over, one under, drive pressure and pass to side.

passes.name: X-Pass
passes.description: Cross your arms to control both legs and pass to the side.

passes.name: Smash Pass
passes.description: Use heavy shoulder pressure to flatten and pass.

passes.name: Hip Switch Pass
passes.description: Open guard, switch hips, and slide knee across to pass.

passes.name: Headquarters Pass
passes.description: Control bottom leg after opening guard to prevent re-guard.

passes.name: Long Step Pass
passes.description: Step one leg back far to break guard, then circle to pass.

passes.name: Bullfighter Pass
passes.description: Stand, control legs, and move side to side to pass quickly.

passes.name: Knee Cut (Inside)
passes.description: Open guard and drive knee through inside position to pass.

passes.name: Leg Weave Pass
passes.description: Weave your leg over/under to systematically clear guard and pass.

submissions.name: Triangle Choke
submissions.description: Use your legs to create a triangle around opponent's neck and arm.

submissions.name: Armbar
submissions.description: Control the arm and extend it over your hip for a joint lock.

submissions.name: Cross Collar Choke
submissions.description: Use your opponent's collar to create a powerful choke.

submissions.name: Guillotine Choke
submissions.description: Wrap your arm around opponent's neck and squeeze with closed guard.

submissions.name: Kimura
submissions.description: Figure-four grip on their arm to attack the shoulder joint.

submissions.name: Omoplata
submissions.description: Use your legs to control and attack their shoulder.

submissions.name: Loop Choke
submissions.description: Feed collar behind their head for a powerful choke.

submissions.name: Ezekiel Choke
submissions.description: Use your own gi sleeve to choke from closed guard bottom.

submissions.name: Straight Armlock (from guard)
submissions.description: Extend arm straight using hip pressure for joint lock.

submissions.name: Gogoplata
submissions.description: Use shin across throat with arm trapped for rare choke.

submissions.name: Baratoplata
submissions.description: Advanced shoulder lock variation combining armbar and omoplata mechanics.

submissions.name: Wrist Locks
submissions.description: Attack posted wrists when opponent defends submissions.

submissions.name: Bicep Slicer
submissions.description: Attack the bicep joint using your legs and arms together.

submissions.name: Bow and Arrow Choke (after sweep)
submissions.description: Transition from back take to finish with collar and pant choke.

submissions.name: Baseball Bat Choke
submissions.description: Use both lapels in baseball bat grip for powerful choke from guard.

guards.name: Spider Guard üï∑Ô∏è
guards.description: Spider guard is an open guard position where you control your opponent's sleeves while placing your feet on their biceps or inside their elbows, creating distance and controlling their posture.
execution: Start from open guard position with hips mobile
Grab both of your opponent's sleeves with strong grips
Place your feet on their biceps, pushing them away
Extend your legs to create tension and stretch them
Keep your hips off the mat and ready to angle
Use one foot to control the hip if doing single spider
Keep constant pressure and movement - never stay static
Combine with collar or pant grips for hybrid positions
Stay ready to transition to lasso, collar sleeve, or other guards
pros: Excellent distance control and management
Multiple sweep opportunities from every angle
Great for controlling aggressive opponents
Allows for transitions to other guards seamlessly
Prevents opponent from establishing strong base
Works well against heavier opponents using their weight
Creates opportunities for sweeps even when they stand
cons: Requires strong grip endurance and forearm strength
Only effective in Gi (sleeves required)
Can be passed with good balance and posture
Difficult against standing leg drag passes
Grips can be broken with proper grip fighting
Energy intensive to maintain for long periods
Vulnerable to stack passes if they get close
tips: Always maintain sleeve grips - if broken, re-establish immediately
Combine with lasso or collar guards for hybrid attacks
Keep your opponent off balance with constant pushing and pulling
Use bicep control to prevent them standing tall
Switch between single and double spider dynamically
Don't just push - pull with grips to create off-balance
Practice grip endurance with specific training
Chain your sweeps - if one fails, flow to another
Use spider to set up triangles and omoplatas

sweeps.name: Spider Sweep (Classic)
sweeps.description: Push with one leg while pulling with grips to sweep opponent to the side.

sweeps.name: Lasso Sweep
sweeps.description: Combine spider and lasso grips for a powerful sweeping motion.

sweeps.name: Triangle Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition from spider to triangle position and sweep or submit.

sweeps.name: Bicep Push Sweep
sweeps.description: Push both biceps strongly while pulling sleeves to sweep backward.

sweeps.name: Sit-up Sweep (Spider variation)
sweeps.description: Come up to sitting while maintaining spider control to sweep forward.

sweeps.name: Overhead Sweep
sweeps.description: Pull them forward over your head using spider grips and leg extension.

sweeps.name: Spider to X-Guard Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition from spider control to X-guard and sweep from there.

sweeps.name: Collar Sleeve Sweep
sweeps.description: Combine collar grip with spider control for powerful angular sweep.

sweeps.name: Spider to De La Riva Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition from spider to DLR position and sweep.

sweeps.name: Reverse Spider Sweep
sweeps.description: Use reverse spider grips (feet on inside of arms) to sweep opposite direction.

sweeps.name: Tripod Sweep (Spider variation)
sweeps.description: Post on one hand while using spider control to sweep to posted side.

sweeps.name: Balloon Sweep (Spider entry)
sweeps.description: Use spider grips to elevate and sweep opponent over your head.

passes.name: Toreando Pass
passes.description: Control the pants and move the legs side to side to pass around spider.

passes.name: Leg Drag
passes.description: Drag one leg across to pass while breaking spider control.

passes.name: Stack Pass
passes.description: Drive their knees to chest, stack weight on shoulders, break grips and pass.

passes.name: Knee Slice
passes.description: Break grips and slice knee through middle to clear spider hooks.

passes.name: Smash Pass
passes.description: Drive forward with pressure to collapse spider structure and pass.

passes.name: Leg Weave Pass
passes.description: Weave legs over/under to systematically clear spider hooks.

passes.name: Double Under Pass
passes.description: Get both arms under legs after breaking grips to secure pass.

passes.name: Backstep Pass
passes.description: Step back and around when they elevate for sweep to pass or take back.

passes.name: Long Step Pass
passes.description: Step one leg way back to clear spider hooks and circle around.

passes.name: Pressure Pass
passes.description: Use chest pressure to break grips and collapse guard structure.

passes.name: Grip Break to Pass
passes.description: Systematically break sleeve grips using proper mechanics then pass.

passes.name: Headquarters Pass
passes.description: Control bottom leg to prevent spider engagement and pass from control.

passes.name: Knee Cut (Outside)
passes.description: Cut knee across from outside after breaking grips to pass to side.

passes.name: Float Pass
passes.description: Float weight over spider hooks while maintaining upper body control.

passes.name: Cartwheel Pass
passes.description: When they invert or go upside down, cartwheel over to pass to mount.

submissions.name: Triangle Choke
submissions.description: Transition from spider guard into triangle position by controlling posture.

submissions.name: Omoplata
submissions.description: Use your legs to attack the shoulder joint from spider control.

submissions.name: Bicep Slicer
submissions.description: Attack the bicep using your legs and gi when they defend sweeps.

submissions.name: Armbar
submissions.description: Swing leg over for armbar when opponent posts or defends from spider.

submissions.name: Collar Choke (Cross Collar)
submissions.description: Use collar grips from spider to set up cross collar choke.

submissions.name: Loop Choke
submissions.description: Set up loop choke from spider guard collar and sleeve control.

submissions.name: Straight Ankle Lock
submissions.description: Transition from spider to ashi garami and attack the ankle.

submissions.name: Toe Hold
submissions.description: Attack the foot from leg entanglement entries off spider transitions.

submissions.name: Wrist Lock
submissions.description: Attack their posted wrist when defending spider guard.

submissions.name: Triangle Armbar (combo)
submissions.description: Transition from triangle attempt to armbar finish.

submissions.name: Baratoplata
submissions.description: Advanced shoulder lock using spider grip and leg control.

submissions.name: Gogoplata
submissions.description: Use shin across throat from spider position for rare choke.

submissions.name: Mounted Triangle
submissions.description: Complete sweep to mount and finish triangle from top.

submissions.name: Kimura
submissions.description: Attack the shoulder when opponent posts or defends from spider.

submissions.name: Baseball Bat Choke
submissions.description: Use collar grips from spider position to set up this powerful choke.

guards.name: De La Riva ü™ù
guards.description: The De La Riva guard is named after Ricardo De La Riva. It involves hooking your opponent's leg from the outside with your leg while controlling their opposite sleeve, creating an asymmetrical control position.
execution: From open guard, identify opponent's lead leg
Hook your outside leg behind their near leg (shin to calf)
Wrap your foot around to their inner thigh for maximum control
Grip their opposite collar or sleeve with a strong grip
Use your other leg to control their hip or bicep
Keep your hips off the mat and mobile
Maintain constant tension pulling them forward
Stay active and create angles by scooting your hips
Keep your shoulders off the mat to prevent being flattened
pros: Excellent for off-balancing opponents
Multiple sweep combinations available
Great for transitioning to other guards
Works well against standing passes
Allows for advanced techniques like berimbolo and back takes
Effective in both Gi and No-Gi (with modifications)
Creates asymmetrical control that disrupts opponent's balance
cons: Complex for beginners to master
Requires good flexibility in the hips
Can be countered by backstep passes
Vulnerable to knee slice if not maintained properly
Requires constant movement and energy
Can be smashed if you get flattened
Leg positioning can be fatiguing to maintain
tips: Keep constant tension on the hook - never let it go slack
Combine with berimbolo attacks for modern game
Control the far sleeve to prevent defensive frames
Practice inversions for advanced attacks and scrambles
Chain your attacks - if sweep fails, transition to another guard
Keep your free leg active - use it to push, frame, or hook
Don't stay static - constantly shift angles and grips
Master the basic DLR sweep before moving to berimbolo
Use collar drag to set up back takes
Practice the kiss of the dragon for advanced back takes

sweeps.name: Classic De La Riva Sweep
sweeps.description: Use the hook and far grip to off-balance and sweep to your hooking side.

sweeps.name: Berimbolo
sweeps.description: Invert under opponent to take the back or sweep - signature modern DLR technique.

sweeps.name: Balloon Sweep
sweeps.description: Elevate opponent using hooks and sweep over your head with momentum.

sweeps.name: Kiss of the Dragon
sweeps.description: Invert completely under opponent, rotate around to take the back.

sweeps.name: Sit-up Sweep (DLR variation)
sweeps.description: Come up to sitting position while maintaining hook to sweep forward.

sweeps.name: Omoplata Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition from DLR hook to omoplata position and sweep.

sweeps.name: Spider-DLR Hybrid Sweep
sweeps.description: Combine spider guard grips with DLR hook for powerful sweep.

sweeps.name: Reverse DLR Sweep
sweeps.description: Use reverse DLR hook (hooking from inside) to sweep opposite direction.

sweeps.name: DLR to X-Guard Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition from DLR to X-guard and sweep from there.

sweeps.name: DLR to Single Leg X Sweep
sweeps.description: Drop to single leg X position and finish sweep from leg entanglement.

sweeps.name: Waiter Sweep
sweeps.description: Control their far leg like a waiter holding a tray and sweep backward.

sweeps.name: Collar Drag to Back Take
sweeps.description: Drag their collar and spin behind for back control or technical sweep.

passes.name: Back Step Pass
passes.description: Step back and around the De La Riva hook to pass to side control or back.

passes.name: Knee Slice
passes.description: Drive the knee through while controlling the hook and clearing it to slice through.

passes.name: Leg Drag
passes.description: Control and drag their bottom leg across to clear the hook and pass.

passes.name: Smash Pass
passes.description: Drive heavy pressure down to flatten them and clear hooks with pressure.

passes.name: Toreando Pass
passes.description: Stand up, control the pants, throw legs to side and pass around.

passes.name: Stack Pass
passes.description: Drive their knees to chest, stack their weight, clear hook and pass.

passes.name: Floating Pass
passes.description: Float over the hook with hip pressure while controlling upper body.

passes.name: Leg Weave Pass
passes.description: Weave your leg over/under to clear the DLR hook systematically.

passes.name: Crossface Pass
passes.description: Heavy crossface to flatten them, then clear hook and circle to side.

passes.name: Pressure Pass
passes.description: Use chest-to-chest pressure to collapse structure and clear hooks.

passes.name: Long Step Pass
passes.description: Step the hooked leg way back to break the hook, then circle around.

passes.name: Headquarters Pass
passes.description: Control their bottom leg in headquarters position to prevent hook engagement.

passes.name: Knee Cut (Outside variation)
passes.description: Cut your knee across from the outside while clearing the DLR hook.

passes.name: Leg Pin Pass
passes.description: Pin their hooking leg down to the mat and pass over it.

passes.name: Cartwheel Pass
passes.description: When inverted for berimbolo, cartwheel over to pass to mount.

submissions.name: Straight Ankle Lock
submissions.description: Control the ankle from De La Riva position and transition to ashi garami.

submissions.name: Triangle Choke
submissions.description: Transition from DLR to triangle setup by controlling posture and getting angle.

submissions.name: Omoplata
submissions.description: Use the DLR hook position to swing leg over for omoplata shoulder lock.

submissions.name: Toe Hold
submissions.description: Attack the foot from leg entanglement entries off DLR.

submissions.name: Knee Bar
submissions.description: Attack the near knee when they defend sweeps or transition to leg locks.

submissions.name: Heel Hook (No-Gi)
submissions.description: Enter heel hook positions from DLR entries in no-gi systems.

submissions.name: Collar Choke (Loop Choke)
submissions.description: Use collar grips from DLR to set up loop choke when they defend.

submissions.name: Armbar
submissions.description: Swing leg over for armbar when opponent posts or defends sweeps.

submissions.name: Back Take to Chokes
submissions.description: Complete berimbolo or kiss of dragon to take back and finish with chokes.

submissions.name: Calf Slicer
submissions.description: Trap their calf with your legs in specific DLR variations.

submissions.name: Wrist Locks
submissions.description: Attack posted hands in no-gi when opponent defends DLR.

submissions.name: Guillotine Choke
submissions.description: Catch the neck as opponent dives in to defend or pass the DLR.

submissions.name: Estima Lock
submissions.description: Attack the foot from DLR entries using specific footlock mechanics.

submissions.name: Baseball Bat Choke
submissions.description: Use collar grips from DLR position to set up this powerful choke.

submissions.name: Bow and Arrow Choke
submissions.description: Transition from back take to finish with bow and arrow from back control.

guards.name: Butterfly Guard ü¶ã
guards.description: Butterfly guard is a seated guard where you use hooks under your opponent's legs while sitting up, allowing for dynamic sweeps and transitions.
execution: Sit with your knees bent and feet inside
Place your feet (hooks) under opponent's thighs
Keep your hooks active with feet flexed and engaged
Control their upper body with collar/sleeve grips
Keep your chest close to theirs
Stay on the balls of your feet ready to elevate
Keep your hips mobile and ready to shift angles
Use underhooks when possible
Create frames with your forearms to manage distance
pros: Powerful sweeps available
Works in both Gi and No-Gi
Great for smaller practitioners
Easy to stand up from
Excellent for entering leg entanglements (especially in no-gi)
Natural position for arm drags and back takes
Low energy expenditure compared to closed guard
cons: Requires awareness of back exposure
Requires good timing
Can be smashed by heavy pressure
Struggles against strong crossface pressure
Can be passed with stack passes if too upright
tips: Get underhooks whenever possible
Elevate and off-balance constantly
Chain your sweeps - if one fails, flow to another
Control the inside space - don't let opponent get double underhooks
Combine with half guard transitions
Practice the butterfly sweep mechanics
Use butterfly guard to stand up in scrambles
Practice your sit-up sweep as a high-percentage option
Drill transitions to X-guard and single leg X

sweeps.name: Sit-up Sweep
sweeps.description: Drive forward and up into opponent while elevating with your hook, coming up to your knees.

sweeps.name: Butterfly Sweep (Classic)
sweeps.description: Elevate with your hook while pulling opponent forward and overhead, rolling them over you.

sweeps.name: Arm Drag to Back Take
sweeps.description: Drag their arm across and take the back for technical sweep or dominant position.

sweeps.name: Hook Sweep (Single Hook)
sweeps.description: Use one butterfly hook to elevate while controlling upper body, sweep to that side.

sweeps.name: Wrestle-up Sweep
sweeps.description: Use butterfly position to come up to your feet and finish a takedown.

sweeps.name: Tripod Sweep
sweeps.description: Post on one hand, use one hook to elevate, sweep to the posted side.

sweeps.name: Butterfly to X-Guard Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition to X-guard position and sweep from there.

sweeps.name: Arm Drag to Single Leg
sweeps.description: Drag the arm and shoot under for a single leg takedown.

sweeps.name: Overhead Sweep
sweeps.description: Pull opponent forward with more backward momentum, rolling completely over.

sweeps.name: Butterfly to Single Leg X
sweeps.description: Drop to single leg X position and sweep from leg entanglement.

sweeps.name: Sickle Sweep
sweeps.description: Hook opponent's ankle with your foot while controlling upper body to sweep.

sweeps.name: Reverse Hook Sweep
sweeps.description: Hook behind their leg instead of under, sweep backward with rotation.

passes.name: Crossface Pass
passes.description: Drive heavy crossface across their face, flatten them, and pass to side control.

passes.name: Double Underhooks Pass
passes.description: Get double underhooks on their arms, drive forward and pass to side.

passes.name: Smash Pass
passes.description: Drive your weight down and forward, collapse their structure, circle around hooks.

passes.name: Toreando Pass
passes.description: Stand up, grip pants/ankles, throw legs to side and pass around.

passes.name: Leg Drag
passes.description: Control their leg and drag it across their body while passing to back or side.

passes.name: Stack Pass
passes.description: Drive their knees to their chest, stack their weight on shoulders, pass around.

passes.name: Knee Slice
passes.description: Slice your knee across their thighs to clear hooks and cut through to side.

passes.name: Sprawl and Smash
passes.description: When they try to come up, sprawl your weight and drive them back down to pass.

passes.name: Headquarters Position
passes.description: Control their bottom leg, prevent hooks from engaging, pass from control.

passes.name: Bodylock Pass
passes.description: Lock around their body, lift or drive them flat, pass to side control.

passes.name: Long Step Pass
passes.description: Step one leg way back to clear hooks, then circle around to pass.

passes.name: Backstep Pass
passes.description: When they elevate for sweep, step back and around to take their back or pass.

passes.name: Bullfighter Pass
passes.description: Stand and push their knees down/away while moving around them quickly.

passes.name: Knee Cut (from standing)
passes.description: Drive knee through middle while controlling upper body to slice through guard.

passes.name: Leg Weave Pass
passes.description: Weave your leg over/under theirs to clear hooks and establish passing control.

submissions.name: Guillotine Choke
submissions.description: Catch the neck as opponent drives forward or dives into guard.

submissions.name: Kimura
submissions.description: Control the wrist and attack the shoulder when opponent posts their arm.

submissions.name: Arm-in Guillotine (High Elbow)
submissions.description: Trap their arm inside the guillotine for added control and finishing power.

submissions.name: Straight Ankle Lock
submissions.description: Transition from butterfly to ashi garami and attack the ankle.

submissions.name: Heel Hook
submissions.description: Enter leg entanglement systems from butterfly (50/50, inside sankaku) and attack heel.

submissions.name: D'Arce Choke
submissions.description: When opponent posts with near arm, wrap D'Arce and roll through to finish.

submissions.name: Front Headlock Chokes
submissions.description: Various chokes when controlling opponent's head from butterfly position.

submissions.name: Anaconda Choke
submissions.description: Similar setup to D'Arce but wrapped from opposite side, roll to finish.

submissions.name: Knee Bar
submissions.description: Attack the near knee when sweeping or transitioning to leg entanglements.

submissions.name: Wrist Locks
submissions.description: Control and attack their posted hand in no-gi situations.

submissions.name: Triangle Choke
submissions.description: Control posture and get angle to throw leg over for triangle.

submissions.name: Omoplata
submissions.description: Transition from butterfly when controlling their arm to attack shoulder.

submissions.name: Toe Hold
submissions.description: Attack the foot from leg entanglement entries off butterfly.

submissions.name: Crucifix
submissions.description: When taking the back from arm drag, trap both arms for crucifix control and submissions.

submissions.name: Armbar
submissions.description: Swing leg over for armbar when opponent posts their arm (less common).

guards.name: Half Guard üõ°Ô∏è
guards.description: Half guard is a position where you control one of your opponent's legs between both of yours while on your back. It's a versatile position that bridges the gap between full guard retention and being passed, offering numerous sweeps and submission opportunities.
execution: Lie on your side with opponent's leg trapped between yours
Control their trapped leg with both your legs locked
Get an underhook on their far side when possible
Keep your inside knee blocking their hip
Stay on your side - never flat on your back
Control their upper body with frames or grips
Keep your head off the mat to prevent crossface
Use your bottom leg to control their ankle/knee
Maintain active hips ready to shift and create angles
pros: Great recovery position when guard is being passed
Works equally well in Gi and No-Gi
Excellent for smaller practitioners against bigger opponents
Multiple sweep and back take opportunities
Can transition to deep half, knee shield, or lockdown variations
Allows defensive players to slow the pace
Natural position for leg lock entries in modern game
cons: Can be smashed by heavy pressure if flat
Vulnerable to crossface and shoulder pressure
Requires constant battle for underhook
Can be difficult to attack if opponent establishes strong base
Risk of being passed if not active
Can be stalled by defensive top players
Requires good timing and technique to sweep effectively
tips: Get the underhook - this is the most important battle
Never let them flatten you - stay on your side
Use knee shield to create distance when needed
Practice deep half guard for modern sweeps
Combine half guard with butterfly hooks for hybrid attacks
Don't stay static - constantly shift between variations
Learn the lockdown for control in Gi and No-Gi
Practice coming up on your elbow/hand for better base
Study the old school sweep as high-percentage option
Chain your attacks - sweep to pass to submission

sweeps.name: Old School Sweep
sweeps.description: Use underhook and leg control to sweep opponent backwards over shoulder.

sweeps.name: Deep Half Sweep (Waiter Sweep)
sweeps.description: Get deep under opponent and sweep them like lifting a tray.

sweeps.name: Homer Simpson Sweep
sweeps.description: Roll under opponent from deep half to sweep or take back.

sweeps.name: Knee Tap Sweep
sweeps.description: Control their far knee and sweep them to that side.

sweeps.name: Electric Chair Sweep
sweeps.description: Use lockdown and lift opponent's leg to sweep or submit.

sweeps.name: Plan B Sweep (Shaolin Sweep)
sweeps.description: Roll under opponent when they defend deep half.

sweeps.name: Underhook Sweep
sweeps.description: Use strong underhook to drive forward and sweep.

sweeps.name: Knee Shield Sweep
sweeps.description: Use knee shield to create space and sweep to side.

sweeps.name: Lockdown Sweep
sweeps.description: Control with lockdown and sweep when they try to escape.

sweeps.name: Half Guard to X-Guard Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition from half to X-guard and sweep from there.

sweeps.name: Single Leg from Half
sweeps.description: Come up to single leg takedown from half guard.

sweeps.name: Back Take Sweep
sweeps.description: Take the back from half guard for technical sweep.

passes.name: Crossface Pass
passes.description: Heavy crossface to flatten them and pass to side control.

passes.name: Knee Slice
passes.description: Slice your trapped knee across to free leg and pass.

passes.name: Underhook Pass
passes.description: Win the underhook battle and drive forward to pass.

passes.name: Leg Drag from Half
passes.description: Control and drag their bottom leg to clear half guard.

passes.name: Backstep Pass
passes.description: Step back and around the half guard to pass or take back.

passes.name: Smash Pass
passes.description: Drive heavy pressure to flatten and clear half guard.

passes.name: Knee Cut (Half Guard)
passes.description: Cut your knee across while controlling upper body.

passes.name: Leg Weave Pass
passes.description: Weave your trapped leg free systematically and pass.

passes.name: Lockdown Counter Pass
passes.description: Break the lockdown and clear leg to pass to side.

passes.name: Hip Switch Pass
passes.description: Switch your hips and free trapped leg to pass.

passes.name: Shoulder of Justice
passes.description: Drive shoulder into thigh to create pain and pass.

passes.name: Kimura Trap Pass
passes.description: Control their arm with kimura grip and pass.

passes.name: Float Pass
passes.description: Float weight over half guard while maintaining control.

passes.name: Stack Pass (Half Guard)
passes.description: Stack their weight and clear trapped leg to pass.

passes.name: Deep Half Counter
passes.description: When they enter deep half, circle hips and pass to mount.

submissions.name: Kimura
submissions.description: Attack the far arm with kimura grip from half guard.

submissions.name: Guillotine Choke
submissions.description: Catch the neck when opponent drives forward in half guard.

submissions.name: Darce Choke

submissions.name: Triangle Choke

submissions.name: Arm-in Guillotine
submissions.description: Trap their arm inside guillotine from half guard.

submissions.name: Electric Chair
submissions.description: Use lockdown to attack their leg/groin from half guard.

submissions.name: Toe Hold
submissions.description: Attack the foot from half guard leg entanglements.

submissions.name: Straight Ankle Lock
submissions.description: Transition to ankle lock from half guard bottom.

submissions.name: Back Take to Chokes

submissions.name: Omoplata

submissions.name: Armbar

submissions.name: Ezekiel Choke
submissions.description: Use gi sleeve to choke from half guard bottom.

submissions.name: Calf Slicer
submissions.description: Attack the calf from deep half guard variations.

submissions.name: Knee Bar

guards.name: X-Guard ‚úñÔ∏è
guards.description: X-Guard is a powerful sweeping position where you control your opponent with both legs forming an 'X' under their body. One leg hooks behind their knee while the other controls their hip, creating excellent elevation and off-balancing opportunities.
execution: Start from open guard or half guard position
Get one foot on their hip (top hook)
Thread your other leg behind their near knee (bottom hook)
Create an X formation with your legs under their body
Control their sleeve or wrist on the trapped leg side
Keep your hips off the mat and mobile
Use your top hook to elevate and control balance
Pull their upper body forward to break posture
Stay ready to transition to single leg X or back take
pros: Extremely powerful sweeping position
Works excellently in both Gi and No-Gi
Great for smaller practitioners against bigger opponents
Natural transition to back takes
Excellent for standing up in scrambles
Multiple sweep angles available
Difficult for opponent to establish base or pressure
cons: Requires good timing to enter the position
Can be vulnerable to guard jumps and knee bars
Requires flexibility in the hips
Can be difficult against opponents who widen their base
Exposed to leg locks if you don't know defense
Requires constant movement and energy
Can be passed if opponent sits or drops weight correctly
tips: Master the entry from half guard and butterfly guard
Always control their upper body - pull them forward
Use your top hook to elevate constantly
Practice the back take as your primary option
Don't stay static - keep elevating and off-balancing
Chain X-guard with single leg X for more options
Study Marcelo Garcia's X-guard system extensively
Learn to stand up from X-guard in scrambles
Practice the technical stand-up sweep
Combine with butterfly hooks for hybrid sweeps

sweeps.name: X-Guard Sweep (Classic)
sweeps.description: Elevate with both hooks and sweep opponent to the side.

sweeps.name: X-Guard to Back Take
sweeps.description: Use X-guard control to transition to back control - Marcelo Garcia signature.

sweeps.name: Technical Stand-up
sweeps.description: Come up to your feet from X-guard while maintaining control.

sweeps.name: Elevator Sweep
sweeps.description: Use bottom hook like elevator to lift and sweep opponent.

sweeps.name: Overhead Sweep
sweeps.description: Pull opponent over your head using X-guard hooks.

sweeps.name: Single Leg X Transition Sweep
sweeps.description: Flow from X-guard to single leg X and sweep.

sweeps.name: Tripod Sweep (from X)
sweeps.description: Post on one hand and use X-guard hooks to sweep.

sweeps.name: Balloon Sweep
sweeps.description: Elevate opponent high and sweep them overhead.

sweeps.name: Reverse X Sweep
sweeps.description: Transition to reverse X-guard position and sweep.

sweeps.name: Hip Bump Sweep (X-guard entry)
sweeps.description: Use X-guard control to sit up and bump sweep.

sweeps.name: Ankle Pick Sweep
sweeps.description: Control ankle from X-guard and sweep their base.

sweeps.name: Crab Ride to Back
sweeps.description: Transition from X-guard to crab ride and take the back.

passes.name: Sit Down Pass
passes.description: Sit down on their bottom hook to break X-guard and pass.

passes.name: Knee Bar Counter

passes.description: Widen your base to prevent elevation and clear hooks.

passes.description: Control their bottom leg and drag across to pass.

passes.description: Drive weight down to collapse X-guard structure.

passes.name: Backstep Pass
passes.description: Step back and around X-guard hooks to pass.

passes.name: Headquarters Pass
passes.description: Establish headquarters to prevent X-guard entry.

passes.name: Stack Pass
passes.description: Stack their weight on shoulders to break X-guard.

passes.name: Leg Weave Pass
passes.description: Weave your legs free from X-guard hooks systematically.

passes.name: Toreando Pass
passes.description: Control legs and throw to side to clear X-guard.

passes.name: Knee Slice
passes.description: Clear hooks and slice knee through to side control.

passes.name: Float Pass
passes.description: Float weight over X-guard while maintaining upper body control.

passes.name: Long Step Pass
passes.description: Step trapped leg way back to break X-guard and circle.

passes.name: Pressure Pass
passes.description: Use heavy chest pressure to flatten and clear X-guard.

passes.name: Reverse X Counter
passes.description: When they go to reverse X, counter with specific pass.
